ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Just live virtual lecture
For MENG 325 I would attend live virtual lectures and also watch the recordings afterward sometimes.
We were able to pick up parts in person, use the CEID for prototyping, and interact with the professor over Zoom for office hours whenever we needed to.
Live, virtual, recorded lecture
Hands-on project toward the end of the class
Construction of parts sent to us.
Office hours

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
This class is the least educational course I have taken at Yale. It is almost the exact same as MENG 185 except you cover how screws and springs are designed. It also taught me that just because someone is a Yale professor, it doesn't mean they are worthy of respect or necessarily intelligent.

In this class, we designed a pistachio crusher... across the course of three months. We had to do psets each week which for the most part marginally helped our rock crusher and more often than not had very little educational opportunity.

I learned how to comb through a textbook for the specific constant I need to ensure my spring doens't break. It's tedious.  But when you're in industry you can't just have stuff break, you need these experimentally derived constants.  So it helped me develop strategies for looking for numbers I need to make the structures I want to build work.  Admittedly very, very useful.

Learned how to design and analyze machine elements, including bearings, shafts, and springs. Also briefly touched on an extensive list of pertinent subtractive and additive manufacturing methods. Concluded the course with the design and fabrication of a pistachio crusher system, using the knowledge we had learned over the semester.
Parts of a machine, how to select for them, how to analyze them, fabrication processes, and also SolidWorks.
Mechanical analysis skills, common machine elements (springs, six-bar mechanism), CAD modeling, manufacturing processes, and effective prototyping
Learned about the manufacturing process, how to calculate the stresses and strengths of individual machine components, and how to iteratively design a project
I learned how to apply physics/statics to analyze a ton about basic machines and how to design a machine from start to finish. I got a lot of hands-on design experience.
Analysis of various machine elements such as bearings, gears, springs and failure modes such as yielding and fatigue

Mechanical design, manufacturing processes, sourcing, kinematic analysis, force analysis, MatLAB. How to develop a mechanical product from research and ideation, through design and analysis, to manufacture.
I learned about manufacturing techniques and the physics behind them.

I learned many new skills through this course, such as basic programming skills and learned how to use a 3D printer. Additionally, I really developed my engineering intuition, and overall learned so many new, interesting engineering concepts.
Linkages, gearing, motor selection, bearing analysis, fatigue, some basics of manufacturing

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
This class was like 90% busy work. The biggest weakness was the creation of our problem sets. They were almost all incredibly long, but not because they informed us of anything. The longest pset we had included a design portion for our final project (~2hrs of work), a written portion with 42 parts (the same 14 parts repeated three times with almost no change ~3hrs of work), and a coding portion.

Almost every pset had a coding portion. This would not have been so bad since everyone in the class is an upperclassperson who should have taken ENAS 130 to learn how to do the coding. However, this was consistently awful. Joran is an actual idiot (more on this later) and designed his code consistently with errors. One night I ended up on a zoom call with eight people trying to figure out code at 4am. Turns out it was literally impossible to get correct. On average, the coding took 7hrs. I have taken CS 223 and this code was more tedious and frustrating than that.

Onto the lectures. Like I said, Joran is an idiot and he doesn't plan his lectures in advance. He for some reason takes pride in this and lets the students know. This means you go through lecture with him deciding to do something and backtracking before it even makes sense. Worse than that, when he does actually have an idea of what he wants to do, you get to watch him flounder through the math and eventually never get it right.

The final project had no advanced analysis done by Joran, so whenever you had to ask him a question, he would say he didn't know and have us ask a TA.

The most time consuming problem set was one where we had to CAD our pistachio crusher. MENG 400 is not a prerequesite so many people had no idea what to do and he only gave an unplanned lecture on how to do CAD once. This made the assignment very difficult. Joran decided to make this part even harder by telling us two seperate times after the assignment was done that the parts we had available were limited so everyone had to redesign the structure multiple times. I would say I spent 30hrs CADing this stupid structure.

Everyone knows that Fluid Lab is the hardest MechE class. The seniors in this class said it rivaled fluids, but at least they learned things in the latter. Joran just had a hard class because he is incompetent.

The way this course could be improved is by hiring Adam (the TA) to teach the class. Whenever a question was asked that was even a little bit technical, Joran had to defer to Adam.

Strengths:  Professor treats students with basic dignity and respect interpersonally.  Thank you for that.  If you lose this respect for your students, the department is screwed.

Weaknesses:  His psets are way too long.  These super long psets makes me feel like he doesn't value my time.  In A5 we did the same problem with 14 parts 3 times.  NOT NECESSARY.  There's a point at which the difficulty of the course increases without gaining anything.  I like the coding aspect though, maybe just have us do code as opposed to writing out 15 pages of work additionally (I counted and it sucked)?

This course contains A LOT of content so, to effectively learn and get through all of it, assignments and lectures need to be well organized. Many of the assignments contained errors (such as in the provided code) that made completing assignments difficult and set back our progress in the class. Fortunately, the professor was extremely accomodating, but better organization would still be preferred.
Weakness: lecture goes kind of fast so be prepared to rewatch lectures (if possible). Strength: this is the best real-life hands-on ME class in my humble onion.

This course is one of the few in the MechE curriculum that actually felt useful for me as an engineer. As a tactile/visual learner, I really enjoyed how the class was centered around a design project and every analysis concept we learned was applied to our project.

I liked the content and lectures were very clear. Professor was always accessible by email/Zoom to discuss assignments. I loved getting to prototype at the end of the semester -- definitely a welcomed change during a semester of Zoom! And Joran is such a nice person to talk to in general.

The only downside on my end would be assignment workload. For most of the problem sets, we had both a coding and a paper portion. I would spend at least 15 hours trying to finish the assignment, often spending a lot of the time coding -- which I get the rationale for, but I felt like was too much, considering that most students know how to code/won't end up coding in MATLAB if they do. 

Sometimes assignments were a bit disorganized. At the end, it felt like a push to pull my designs together and order parts, especially because random aspects changed. Prof/TA's did their best, though, and were accommodating with extensions. They also allowed multiple opportunities to make up work and gave thorough feedback which was really helpful.

One of the great strengths of the course was the varied methods of lecturing material that Prof Booth employed. Some notes he took digitally, some he used powerpoints for, and there was even a lecture or two that he pointed a camera at the blackboard and used that. He also made sure to reference where the material was coming from in the textbook, which made it easier to look up later for clarification or formulas. Apparently there were changes made to the curriculum since last year. For the most part, I feel like they were successful, although there was significant trial and error in both material taught and homework content. The final design project was limited in its accessibility due to COVID-19 guidelines, but nonetheless it was awesome to be able to build a project with creative liberty and see it come together over the course of the semester.

Strengths - really cool assignments, really interesting content, I felt like this was one of the first MechE classes I took that helped me understand what it would actually be like to work as an engineer in the real world.
Weaknesses - the assignments can be really complex/long, and once the answer key for code we had to write was wrong which caused a lot of problems. However, Professor Booth and Adam (the TA) were really good about owning up to any mistakes they made and were super lenient when it came to extending deadlines/allowing resubmissions/etc. Also, and this wasn't any fault of the teaching staff, but it was kind of a bummer that due to COVID-10 we couldn't get the hands-on machining experience that typically accompanies the class.

Strengths: hands-on project gives you a chance to use parts and components you learn about in an actual project. Also gives you handy reference for calculations in engineering design (will probably be useful in senior design)

Weaknesses: Fairly disorganized, could be structured better. A lot of the negatives were mostly because of the course not being well adapted to remote learning.

The project-based nature of the course made it the course I cared about most this entire semester. Everything we did in lecture was applied in our weekly assignments that built towards our final product. I could understand what I was doing, and I actually liked it. The workload was initially too heavy but Prof. Booth, and the teaching staff were very attentive to student concerns and adjusted the syllabus accordingly.

The strengths are the teaching staff (Joran, Adam, Rowan) always being extremely supportive, the interesting/engaging material, and the development of engineering intuition. A possible weakness was the pretty intensive Psets in the first few weeks (although this may just have been because I was new to coding, etc.), but I learned a ton from these so I cant really complain.

The course is very practical, and lays out clear tools for engineering analysis.  The course topics due feel somewhat disjoint, and it would be helpful to spend a little more time on first principles and greater context.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The process for acquiring building material was rather messy. Maybe a system where students order some of their own material (within a budget) and are reimbursed would go more smoothly.

The lectures were transitioned to recorded live zoom calls during which Prof. Booth wrote notes/equations on screen and then also published the notes sheet at students' request. Although the logistics of organizing distribution of parts for our build at the end of the semester seemed very rough for everyone due to covid, whenever a challenge like this came up in the course, Prof. Booth was extremely understanding and accommodating. Of course, the assembly portion of our build projects would have been a lot easier if we were all on campus, but it went much smoother than I expected considering restrictions.
Remote teaching was well-performed, recordings were helpful for reviewing content, adequate office hours and feedback on designs/assignments, enough  chances given for ordering/prototyping.

There were definitely aspects of this class that were inaccessible due to the pandemic, but it seemed that Prof Booth was making every effort to counter his setbacks so that the class could be as robust as possible.

Virtual lectures were good, I appreciate that Prof. Booth did not just throw a bunch of lecture slides at us and instead wrote through equations and derivations via screen sharing. With any hands-on class like this, it is going to be difficult to adapt it to be completely virtual. There were a lot of hiccups with ordering and distributing parts for the final project, but Prof. Booth really put in a lot of effort into making the most out of a difficult situation. I think there could be better planning, for example the motor we used in our designs was not the motor we received for the build, which led to a lot of redesigning and fabrication.

Prof. Booth was the most adaptable professor I have ever had. His willingness to change his approach and the course in general made 325 a fantastic class and greatly helped my learning and mental health.
The online lectures were a success and the manufacturing project went very well considering the online setting.

Office hours definitely still succeeded to help me learn. Not only were all the staff very helpful, they were willing to meet with you over zoom at any time just to help you find even a simple coding mistake or math error. The project based nature of many of these assignments definitely succeeded as well.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
I would not recommend this course to anyone. Not to a mech e and certainly not to anyone outside of the major.

This was the most disappointing frustrating class I have ever taken. Nothing was mentally very challenging, but each pset was designed to cause the maximum amount of frustration. Joran claims that he doesn't like giving busy work, but this is my third class with him and it is all he assigns.

Check the strengths/weaknesses section and read the long one. I am exhausted of typing but believe me this class is just tedious and boring and way too much work.

Do you want to be a practicing engineer?  Well grow a metaphorical pair (testicles, ovaries or other organs that represent toughness) and recognize that part of engineering IS searching for obscure constants in a book.  It sucks yah, but this work needs to be done if you want to be taken seriously.  Knowing how to do it well is important, and, whether conscious or not, Joran forces you to do it.

If you are NOT ABET.  Don't take this course.  Material is applicable for those who WANT TO BECOME ENGINEERS IN INDUSTRY.  Be warned abet students.  psets had mistakes in them which at times made them impossible to complete.  I logged 20 hours CADing and re-CADing a mechanism because the professor's motor selection was incorrect.  The physics is wrong in some psets, which is.... really bad.  BUT, the applicable skills in this course make me believe this is worth it.
Required for mechE majors, don't see a reason to take it otherwise.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student. This was genuinely fun and hands-on, but some assignments take many hours of work. I learned so many intangible engineering skills in this class that I could not have learned from reading a book.

I would most definitely recommend this class! This is obviously a required course for many of the people who take it, but I felt that everything I learned in this class was useful and interesting, and I genuinely think this class was the highlight of my semester. If you enjoy design projects, it's 100% for you. On the other hand, if you're not super interested in the building/tactile side of MechE, it would still probably seem valuable, but it may not be as enjoyable for you, since it can get pretty time intensive and it may not seem as worth it.

I really liked this course; however, you should be really prepared for the workload, which I expect will change next semester. Joran is one of the few professors in the MechE department I've had that has been willing/able to prep me for industry. Dynamics would be helpful for this class as a pre-req and strength+def is definitely required, so make sure you have these plus some CAD/MATLAB before you take it.

This class is a doozy. The workload is like nothing I have ever encountered in a Yale course before. I would greatly caution you against taking this if workload concerns are an issue. Besides that, I highly recommend this course. I enjoyed very much how tangible the material was and how well it complimented the previous curricula of the major. It was awesome to design and build our project too, and I would imagine that being able to use the machine shops during a normal year would also be a huge boon. And yes, I have a 3D printer. Awesome class.

I would absolutely recommend this course to people who are interested in working as engineers. You're probably not taking this class unless you are a junior/senior MechE, and it's required for ABET, but I would strongly recommend it for anybody who is interested and has taken all of the prerequisites.

Take it if it's offered entirely in-person, you'll probably have a better experience. If you're MechE ABET try and take this in your junior year so you'll be more prepared for senior design (at least that's my guess, I'm still a junior).
Absolutely. It's a ton of work but if you like mechanical engineering and mechanical design, it's worth it.
I would highly recommend this class because professor booth cares a lot about his students and the content is very interesting.

This class, although difficult at times, taught me the basics pertaining to invaluable skills such as 3D printing, programming, CAD, and overall mechanical design. Additionally, it provided me with many tools to further develop these skills, and more, in the future. I would definitely urge a fellow classmate to take this class, with Joran Booth as the Professor.
Yes, I think the course is essential for showing how engineers can think through/approach practical design problems.
